intro: Lycianthes parasitica var. campylorhachis, commonly known as the waxy beggar's-ticks, is a member of the Solanaceae family. It is a climbing shrub that produces small, yellowish flowers and later develops berries that are typically yellow or orange in color. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, which are often glandular and can exude a sticky substance. It is native to Central and South America and is often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and waste areas. The species is known for its parasitic tendencies, although it may also grow semi-parasitically on other plants.
